body: Pei Li Tsang sipped from a cup of tea as she sat on a couch in her Sheepshead Bay apartment. Her shy daughter, Anny, 10, a professed bookworm, read a Harry Potter novel while her brother, Jason, 7, laughed at a car chase on television. It was a good moment. Peaceful. Satisfying. They had left China to come to America for moments just like this one.
title: The Neediest Cases; As Chinese Immigrants Struggle in a Strange Land, Just Asking for Help Is a Challenge

body: The views are not commanding, unless you count the one of the exhaust stations for the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel. title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RED HOOK; In Area Where Capone Roamed, Inn Burnishes a Changing Image

title: Residential Real Estate; Subsidy Program Makes Its Way to Brooklyn

body: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, still hindered by a less-than-robust regional economy and the demands of rebuilding and heightened security after the Sept. 11 terror attack, approved a $4.5 billion budget yesterday that board members said was little changed from spending levels last year and the year before. title: Port Authority Budget Is Approved on Schedule

body: High school principals and deans say the city's system for suspending violent students is in disarray, sometimes resulting in three-week delays before dangerous students can be removed from the schools. The officials say that in the overhaul of the city's school bureaucracy this year, a newly centralized disciplinary process proved too slow --
title: City's New System Delays Suspensions Of Violent Students

title: Man Acquitted Of a Murder In Brooklyn

body: A meeting of the YankeeNets board, at which four bids to acquire the Nets were to be presented, was postponed yesterday because a long-awaited agreement to split up the YankeeNets was not completed in time, two officials involved in the transactions said. The meeting could be rescheduled quickly upon the resolution of outstanding issues in the
title: PRO BASKETBALL; Delay in YankeeNets Breakup Makes Bidders for Nets Wait

body: The YankeeNets board is expected to meet this afternoon in Manhattan to begin considering the four bids to acquire the Nets. The board will hear details of the offers and recommendations from its investment bankers, Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers. The highest bidder is Bruce Ratner, at $275 million, followed by Charles Wang at $265 million,
title: PRO BASKETBALL; 4 Bids for Nets to Be Reviewed

body: Tristine Skyler is intrigued by waiting rooms. Her first film, ''Getting to Know You,'' was set in a bus station waiting room. Her first play, ''The Moonlight Room,'' which opened earlier this month at the TriBeCa Playhouse, takes place in a hospital waiting room. ''I like writing about waiting rooms,'' Ms. Skyler said in a recent interview. ''I
title: Well-Observed Waiting, And a Fruitful First Play

body: Striding into the airport here one recent afternoon, Kimberly Ward did not so much as glance at the two ticket agents waiting at the counter. Like most of her fellow travelers, she instead claimed an automated check-in terminal, touched its screen a few times, and took the proferred boarding pass with a quick smile of thanks. Ms. Ward, 37, pays for
title: More Consumers Reach Out to Touch the Screen

body: Seymour Cohn, co-founder and chairman of the Sylvan Lawrence Company, long a major commercial real estate power in New York City, died on Thursday. He was 92. title: Seymour Cohn, 92, a Founder Of a New York Realty Giant

body: Some teams are put up for sale and are sold. It's not that easy for the money-losing Nets, who have attracted four potential buyers. The winner could pay $300 million or more, well more than they are worth. But this is not a simple transaction. And there is no guarantee of a sale, which tends to be confusing to willing buyers. YankeeNets could sell
title: SPORTS BUSINESS; A YankeeNets Split Is Not a Simple, Straightforward Transaction

body: IT'S hard to take a cheese seriously when it shares its name with both a subatomic particle and a computer application. Or, perhaps, it's hard to take the subatomic particle or the application seriously since they share their name with a cheese. However you look at it, quark, the cheese, has always deserved both its own identity and more respect.
title: Cheese for Rocket Scientists, and Others

body: Four bids to buy the Nets from YankeeNets were submitted yesterday, including one that was unexpected, according to three people involved in the process. None of the bids exceeded $300 million, and the highest one was separated from the lowest by about $30 million, two of the people said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The three who submitted
title: PRO BASKETBALL; 4 Bids Entered to Buy Nets From YankeeNets

body: Until last year, the Working Families Party seemed invisible in New York City politics -- so much so that its own members carried around a giant cardboard cutout of an H to call attention to the party's line on the ballot, the very last column. Now it can carry another letter: W, but this time for winner. The liberal-leaning party scored one of the
title: A Third Party Makes Its First Mark

body: EVERY year I am offered a seat in a pace car of the New York City Marathon. To paraphrase Mel Brooks, it's good to be the sports columnist. The 26-mile, 385-yard tour via cordoned roads invokes the same reaction every year: I pledge to get in better running shape, and I renew my love vows for my hometown. Mostly, I get hungry. My attention span
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: URBAN STUDIES/SALIVATING; 26.2 Miles of Food

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK REPUTATIONS; Another Advertisement For Mailer

title: Ferry Captain Appears in Court but Remains Silent on Crash

body: WANDERING around Brooklyn in a skirt when you are a dude is a complicated affair, fraught with loaded symbols and multiple entendres, but three simple rules will get you a long way: * Take short strides. * Make no eye contact, except with people who are already yelling at you. * No matter what, stay out of the ABC Super Stores branch in the Fulton
title: Guy in Skirt Seeks Sensitivity In Brooklyn

body: Last Sunday, as her night shift neared, Kim Brathwaite faced a hard choice. Her baby sitter had not shown up, and to miss work might end her new position as assistant manager at a McDonald's in downtown Brooklyn. So she left her two children, 9 and 1, alone, trying to stay in touch by phone. It turned out to be a disastrous decision. Someone, it
title: Daily Choice Turned Deadly: Children Left on Their Own

author: Jonathan Mahler is writing a book on New York and baseball in the 70's. His last article for the magazine was about the Lubavitch Hasidic sect.
body: Officer Wilton Sekzer was in the living room of his apartment in Sunnyside, Queens, on the night of July 13, 1977, when his lights went out. On the way to check his fuse box, he peeked out the window. The whole block was dark. Sekzer ran up three flights to his roof. He looked to the west, across the East River, to Manhattan. title: The Darkest Night

title: PUBLIC LIVES; Third-Party Organizer Works for Populism's Future

body: For decades in New York, the law has required that political parties nominate candidates to run for State Supreme Court at judicial conventions, not in primaries. title: Picking Judges: Party Machines, Rubber Stamps

title: Taking Gloves Off to Save a Gym; 3 Boxers Add Acting, Math and Computer Classes

title: POSTINGS: Linking Dancers and Rehearsal Space; Square Feet For Toe Shoes

body: DEAR DIARY: Freed by my wife from the usual parental cares on Father's Day, I went off to play pickup chess in Central Park. As its aficionados understand, chess is no less macho than football or rugby. So it was uncommonly awkward when, moments after I sat down, a bold 8-year-old boy asked if I wanted to play. Chess with children is a losing
title: Metropolitan Diary

body: Mike Tyson was arrested at a hotel in downtown Brooklyn early yesterday morning after fighting two men and knocking one of them unconscious, the police said. The fight began just after 5:30 a.m., a law enforcement official said. Tyson, a former heavyweight champion, and his sister were waiting in the lobby of the Marriott Hotel on Adams Street for
title: BOXING; Tyson Arrested After Fight in Hotel Lobby

body: When a slightly pudgy Lennox Lewis began his fight with the challenger Vitali Klitschko, Lewis moved with the speed and urgency of an overworked man taking a long lunch break. This was not a sharp Lewis. This was a tired-looking, cocky Lewis, who looked as if he had eaten one too many hot dogs the past few days, and he fought that way, too. Lewis
title: BOXING; Lewis Cuts The Deepest And Retains His Title

body: IF a Brooklyn man stumbled while walking on Fulton Street in the morning, so the old saying went, he could read about it that evening in The Eagle. Now, more than 100 years later, everyone else can read about it, too. They can also read about every grisly murder, every women's suffrage rally and every new corset style to grace the pages of The
title: CITY LORE; A Newspaper of Record, Recorded

title: Fashion Tip in Rap For Brooklyn Girls

body: For seven years, Awilda Vazquez was treading water on welfare, struggling to raise her two daughters, but then she got her big chance, landing a job as a $30,000-a-year clerk in the New York Fire Department. title: From Work To Welfare Reversal Seen In City Layoffs

Bloomberg announced yesterday. The new court, which began hearing cases on April 28,
title: A Special Court for Gun Crimes Is Created Just for Five Neighborhoods in Central Brooklyn

body: Those brass-colored subway tokens now collecting dust in dresser drawers across the city are still worth $1.50, technically. But riders should not try to use them to help pay the $2 fare that went into effect yesterday. And they should not try to redeem them at the local subway stop. The only way to cash in the tokens is by visiting, by appointment
title: Subway Token: Currency of the Past

title: Panel Supports Crisis Center In Brooklyn

title: Brooklyn Critics Win Delay Of Vote on Disaster Center

title: Brooklyn Judge Faces Charges Of Corruption

body: New York City will invest roughly $100 million over the next 7 to 10 years to make Downtown Brooklyn a vibrant commercial and residential hub, officials said yesterday, as part of a Bloomberg administration plan to keep jobs within the five boroughs, and to attract others. body: Bear, Stearns & Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to renew its lease at MetroTech Center in Brooklyn instead of moving 1,500 jobs to Manhattan or New Jersey. The announcement came after the city agreed last week to restructure $4.8 million in tax exemptions from an earlier subsidy deal. The investment bank's chairman, James E. Cayne,
title: Bear, Stearns Accepts Deal To Keep Workers in Brooklyn

title: Arrest in Holdup at College

The holdup led to the evacuation of the entire campus and prompted the police to close about 20 blocks in Downtown
title: Gunman Robs Guards Filling Cash Machine at L.I.U.

title: TUNNEL VISION; Next Stop, 'Twilight Zone' (a k a 76th St. Station)

title: Bear Stearns And City Hall At an Impasse On Tax Breaks

title: POSTINGS: Downtown Brooklyn Project; Reborn Building to Aid the Arts
